DataElement.preferredName: Dynamic Susceptibility Contrast Magnetic Resonance Imaging Cerebral Mean Transit Time Second Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Value to capture the mean time course of a contrast agent in cerebrovascular tissue; analyzed to gain information about blood supply and potential pathology in the site. [Manually-curated]

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Dynamic Susceptibility Contrast Magnetic Resonance Imaging Cerebral Mean Transit Time
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The constitutional or inborn state disposing to a disease, group of diseases, or metabolic or structural anomaly._The degree of difference between the lightest and darkest areas of an image or object._Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders._(seh-REE-bral HEM-iss-feer) One half of the cerebrum, the part of the brain that controls muscle functions and also controls speech, thought, emotions, reading, writing, and learning. The right hemisphere controls the muscles on the left side of the body, and the left hemisphere controls the muscles on the right side of the body._The sum of a set of values divided by the number of values in the set._Substances administered during diagnostic procedures that allows delineation of internal structures.  Contrast agents appear opaque due to the difference in absorption of X-rays or other electromagnetic waves and surrounding tissue._the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The constitutional or inborn state disposing to a disease, group of diseases, or metabolic or structural anomaly.:The degree of difference between the lightest and darkest areas of an image or object.:Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: The constitutional or inborn state disposing to a disease, group of diseases, or metabolic or structural anomaly.
The degree of difference between the lightest and darkest areas of an image or object.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Property.preferredName: Cerebral Hemisphere Mean Contrast Agent Time
Property.preferredDefinition: (seh-REE-bral HEM-iss-feer) One half of the cerebrum, the part of the brain that controls muscle functions and also controls speech, thought, emotions, reading, writing, and learning. The right hemisphere controls the muscles on the left side of the body,:The sum of a set of values divided by the number of values in the set.:Substances used in radiography that allow visualization of certain tissues.:the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.

Concepts.definition: The part of the brain that controls muscle functions and also controls speech, thought, emotions, reading, writing, and learning. The right hemisphere controls the muscles on the left side of the body, and the left hemisphere controls the muscles on the right side of the body.
The sum of a set of values divided by the number of values in the set.

Substances administered during imaging procedures that allows delineation of internal structures. Contrast agents appear opaque due to the difference in absorption of X-rays or other electromagnetic waves and surrounding tissue.
The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Numeric value with no fractional part to represent a value of seconds._The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past._A unit of time, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). The second is the duration of 919 263 177 0 periods of the specified light radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the caesium 133 atom in its ground state at 0 K. According to the convention, 60 seconds constitute one minute; 3,600 seconds constitute one hour._A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.:The second is the unit of time, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). The second is the duration of 919 263 177 0 periods of the specified light radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the ground state of the caesium 133 atom in its ground state at 0 K. According to the convention, 60 seconds constitute one minute; 3,600 seconds constitute one hour. Abbreviation Sec. is acceptable in non-scientific usage only.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.

A unit of time, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). The second is the duration of 919 263 177 0 periods of the specified light radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the caesium 133 atom in its ground state at 0 K. According to the convention, 60 seconds constitute one minute; 3,600 seconds constitute one hour.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated to support MGH adoption of C3D
